verses.text: Now Pashur the son of Immer the priest, who \add was\add* also chief governor in the house of the \sc Lord\sc*, heard \add that\add* Jeremiah prophesied these things.
Then Pashur smote Jeremiah the prophet, and put him in the stocks that \add were\add* in the high gate of Benjamin, which \add was\add* by the house of the \sc Lord\sc*.
And it came to pass on the morrow, that Pashur brought forth Jeremiah out of the stocks. Then said Jeremiah unto him, The \sc Lord\sc* hath not called thy name Pashur, but Magor-missabib.

For thus saith the \sc Lord\sc*, Behold, I will make thee a terror to thyself, and to all thy friends: and they shall fall by the sword of their enemies, and thine eyes \add shall\add* behold \add it;\add* and I will give all Judah into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he shall carry them captive into Babylon, and shall slay them with the sword.

Moreover I will deliver all the strength of this city, and all the labours thereof, and all the precious things thereof, and all the treasures of the kings of Judah will I give into the hand of their enemies, which shall spoil them, and take them, and carry them to Babylon.

And thou, Pashur, and all that dwell in thine house shall go into captivity: and thou shalt come \add to\add* Babylon, and there thou shalt die, and shalt be buried there, thou, and all thy friends, to whom thou hast prophesied lies.
O \sc Lord\sc*, thou hast deceived me, and I was deceived: Thou art stronger than I, and hast prevailed: I am in derision daily, Every one mocketh me.
For since I spake, I cried out, I cried violence and spoil; Because the word of the \sc Lord\sc* was made a reproach unto me, And a derision, daily.

Then I said, I will not make mention of him, Nor speak any more in his name. But \add his word\add* was in mine heart as a burning fire shut up in my bones, And I was weary with forbearing, and I could not stay.

For I heard the defaming of many, fear on every side. Report, \add say they\add*, and we will report it. All my familiars watched for my halting, \add saying\add*, Peradventure he will be enticed, and we shall prevail against him, And we shall take our revenge on him.

But the \sc Lord\sc* \add is\add* with me as a mighty terrible one: Therefore my persecutors shall stumble, and they shall not prevail: They shall be greatly ashamed: for they shall not prosper: \add Their\add* everlasting confusion shall never be forgotten.
But, O \sc Lord\sc* of hosts, that triest the righteous, \add And\add* seest the reins and the heart, Let me see thy vengeance on them: For unto thee have I opened my cause.
Sing unto the \sc Lord\sc*, praise ye the \sc Lord\sc*: For he hath delivered the soul of the poor from the hand of evildoers.
Cursed \add be\add* the day wherein I was born: Let not the day wherein my mother bare me be blessed.
Cursed \add be\add* the man who brought tidings to my father, saying, A man child is born unto thee; Making him very glad.
And let that man be as the cities which the \sc Lord\sc* overthrew, and repented not: And let him hear the cry in the morning, and the shouting at noontide;
Because he slew me not from the womb; Or that my mother might have been my grave, And her womb \add to be\add* always great \add with me\add*.
Wherefore came I forth out of the womb To see labour and sorrow, That my days should be consumed with shame?
